SNIPPET: "AT last the sleepy atmosphere was stirredâ€”and vigorously: the murder trial came on in the court. It became the absorbing topic of village talk immediately. Tom could not get away from it. Every reference to the murder sent a shudder to his heart, for his troubled conscience and fears almost persuaded him that these remarks were put forth in his hearing as â€œfeelersâ€; he did not see how he could be suspected of knowing anything about the murder, but still he could not be comfortable in the midst of this gossip. It kept him in a cold shiver all the time. He took Huck to a lonely place to have a talk with him. It would be some relief to unseal his tongue for a little while; to divide his burden of distress with another sufferer. Moreover, he wanted to assure himself that Huck had remained discreet.\nâ€œHuck, have you ever told anybody aboutâ€”that?â€\nâ€œ'Bout what?â€\nâ€œYou know what.â€\nâ€œOhâ€”'course I haven't.â€\nâ€œNever a word?â€\nâ€œNever a solitary word, so help me. What makes you ask?â€\nâ€œWell, I was afeard.â€\nâ€œWhy, Tom Sawyer, we wouldn't be alive two days if that got found out. You know that.â€\nTom felt more comfortable. After a pause:\nâ€œHuck, they couldn't anybody get you to tell, could they?â€\nâ€œGet me to tell? Why, if I wanted that halfbreed devil to drownd me they could get me to tell. They ain't no different way.â€\nâ€œWell, that's all right, then. I reckon we're safe as long as we keep mum. But let's swear again, anyway. It's more surer.â€\nâ€œI'm agreed.â€\nSo they swore again with dread solemnities.\nâ€œWhat is the talk around, Huck? I've heard a power of it.â€\nâ€œTalk? Well, it's just Muff Potter, Muff Potter, Muff Potter all the time. It keeps me in a sweat, constant, so's I want to hide som'ers.â€\nâ€œThat's just the same way they go on round me. I reckon he's a goner. Don't you feel sorry for him, sometimes?â€\nâ€œMost alwaysâ€”most always. He ain't no account; but then he hain't ever done anything to hurt anybody. Just fishes a little, to get money to get drunk onâ€”and loafs around considerable; but lord, we all do thatâ€”leastways most of usâ€”preachers and such like. But he's kind of goodâ€”he give me half a fish, once, when there warn't enough for two; and lots of times he's kind of stood by me when I was out of luck.â€\nâ€œWell, he's mended kites for me, Huck, and knitted hooks on to my line. I wish we could get him out of there.â€\nâ€œMy! we couldn't get him out, Tom. And besides, 'twouldn't do any good; they'd ketch him again.â€\nâ€œYesâ€”so they would. But I hate to hear 'em abuse him so like the dickens when he never doneâ€”that.â€\nâ€œI do too, Tom. Lord, I hear 'em say he's the bloodiest looking villain in this country, and they wonder he wasn't ever hung before.â€\nâ€œYes, they talk like that, all the time. I've heard 'em say that if he was to get free they'd lynch him.â€\nâ€œAnd they'd do it, too.â€\nThe boys had a long talk, but it brought them little comfort. As the twilight drew on, they found themselves hanging about the neighborhood of the little isolated jail, perhaps with an undefined hope that something would happen that might clear away their difficulties. But nothing happened; there seemed to be no angels or fairies interested in this luckless captive.\nThe boys did as they had often done beforeâ€”went to the cell grating and gave Potter some tobacco and matches. He was on the ground floor and there were no guards."
]
